ygData.subject: Re: Newbie question
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Max There is a bug in neat4j when you specify more than one output (Doh!). If you go to the sourceforge site for neat4j then there is a fix documented.

Hi Max

There is a bug in neat4j when you specify more than one output (Doh=
!).
 If you go to the sourceforge site for neat4j then there is a fix
docum=
ented.

Follow this link.

https://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=
=3Ddetail&aid=3D1594074&group_id=3D175856&atid=3D874910

Basically, the ini=
tialisation does not populated the correct genes.

Synopsis below.

The pro=
blem is caused by the generation of the initial
population in the class
org=
.neat4j.neat.core.InnovationDatabase.

At the lines 104 and 105 the calcula=
tion of the
array-indexes are probably wrong.

Instead of:
----------------=
-----
links[(i * outputs) + j] =3D
this.submitLinkInnovation(nodes[j].id(),=
 nodes[inputs +
i].id());
links[(i * outputs) +
j].setWeight(MathUtils.next=
PlusMinusOne());
---------------------
there should be:
-------------------=
--
links[(i*inputs)+j]=3Dthis.submitLinkInnovation(nodes[j].id(),nodes[inpu=
ts+i]
.id());
links[(i*inputs)+j].setWeight(MathUtils.nextPlusMinusOne());
=
---------------------
Otherwise not the full array of the size of
inputs*ou=
tputs is initailized. And this will be the
reason for the nullpointer.

Che=
ers

Matt


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "cicilanov" <maxc@...> wrote:
>
> =
